player_decision.reason: 3-handed preflop with KJo? Actually Kd Js, in a 3-handed game you are the btn and should raise. Raise to 20 (min raise) to steal blinds and take initiative, with fold equity and decent postflop potential.

6 BB in the small blind facing a button min-raise; 86o is too weak to reshove and flatting OOP with an SPR <1 is poor. Preserve chips for the next hand on the button where we’ll have better fold equity.
Suited connectors (8c6c) in big blind vs a single small raise — good pot and implied odds to see a flop. Avoid unnecessary risk with a medium-strength hand and preserve my larger stack.
8c6c on 7c 2s Ad has an open-ended straight draw (8 outs) plus backdoor club possibilities — decent equity (~30–35%). Call to see the turn rather than folding or overcommitting with a draw.
On an Ace-high flop with Kd Js and a shallow stack, there are no good outs. Checking (via Call) to see turn and evaluate further is the safer path and preserves a later fold if the turn bricks.

I have a strong club flush draw (10 outs, ~21.7% to hit the river) but no made hand; the board is double‑A which makes opponents likely to have strong pairs. Calling preserves chips and realizes my equity on the river rather than committing with a semi‑bluff or folding a draw.

You have a marginal hand (Kd Js) on an Ace-high board with little to no real outs. There is likely a strong range from the opponent. Shoving all-in maximizes your fold equity and gives you a chance to double up if your opponent folds or is uncertain, preserving tournament life.

With A A 7 2 board and 8c6c I have no pair and cannot make a straight or flush with one card to come (virtually no equity). Charlie’s all‑in is likely an Ace/pair; calling risks most of my stack with a very poor chance to win. Preserve my big stack and fold.
